445.title: SMB/CIFS Information Disclosure
445.description: SMB (Server Message Block) service is running on port 445. This service can be vulnerable to information disclosure attacks if not properly configured. Attackers may be able to enumerate shares, users, and system information.
445.remediation: 1. Disable SMB if not required. 2. Apply latest Windows security updates. 3. Configure SMB signing. 4. Restrict network access to SMB ports. 5. Use SMB version 3.0 or higher.

445.title: EternalBlue SMB Vulnerability (MS17-010)
445.description: Critical vulnerability in Microsoft SMB protocol that allows remote code execution. This vulnerability was exploited by WannaCry and NotPetya ransomware attacks. Affects Windows systems with unpatched SMB implementations.
445.remediation: 1. Immediately apply Microsoft Security Bulletin MS17-010. 2. Disable SMBv1 protocol. 3. Block SMB ports (445, 139) at network perimeter. 4. Enable Windows Firewall. 5. Implement network segmentation.

445.title: SMB Null Session Enumeration
445.description: SMB service allows null session connections, which can be exploited to enumerate system information, user accounts, and network shares without authentication. This provides attackers with valuable reconnaissance information.
445.remediation: 1. Disable null session access in Windows registry. 2. Configure 'Network access: Do not allow anonymous enumeration of SAM accounts' policy. 3. Set 'Network access: Restrict anonymous access to Named Pipes and Shares' policy. 4. Apply principle of least privilege for share permissions.

445.title: SMB Signing Not Enforced
445.description: SMB signing is not enforced, making the system vulnerable to man-in-the-middle attacks and SMB relay attacks. Attackers can intercept and modify SMB communications or relay authentication to other systems.
445.remediation: 1. Enable SMB signing on both client and server. 2. Configure 'Microsoft network server: Digitally sign communications (always)' policy. 3. Configure 'Microsoft network client: Digitally sign communications (always)' policy. 4. Implement network monitoring for unsigned SMB traffic.

445.title: SMBv1 Protocol Enabled
445.description: The deprecated SMBv1 protocol is enabled on this system. SMBv1 has numerous security vulnerabilities and performance issues. It should be disabled in favor of SMBv2 or SMBv3.
445.remediation: 1. Disable SMBv1 protocol completely. 2. Upgrade to SMBv2 or SMBv3. 3. Audit network for SMBv1 usage before disabling. 4. Update legacy applications that depend on SMBv1. 5. Monitor event logs for SMBv1 usage attempts.

22.title: Weak SSH Configuration
22.description: The SSH service is running but may be vulnerable due to weak ciphers or lack of two-factor authentication.
22.remediation: 1. Disable weak ciphers. 2. Enforce key-based authentication. 3. Use fail2ban to limit brute-force.

80.title: HTTP Service Without HTTPS
80.description: HTTP detected without HTTPS fallback. Transmitted data could be intercepted or manipulated.
80.remediation: 1. Redirect HTTP to HTTPS. 2. Implement TLS 1.2 or higher. 3. Use HSTS headers.

3389.title: Exposed RDP Service
3389.description: RDP service is exposed and may be vulnerable to brute-force or BlueKeep-like attacks.
3389.remediation: 1. Disable RDP if not required. 2. Use VPN. 3. Apply BlueKeep patch. 4. Use NLA authentication.

21.title: Anonymous FTP Access
21.description: FTP allows anonymous access. Sensitive files could be exposed.
21.remediation: 1. Disable anonymous FTP. 2. Switch to SFTP. 3. Audit public file access.

23.title: Telnet Service Detected
23.description: Telnet transmits credentials in cleartext and should be avoided.
23.remediation: 1. Disable Telnet. 2. Use SSH instead. 3. Monitor for unexpected connections.

9999.title: Custom Service Detected on Port 9999
9999.description: A non-standard service is running on port 9999. This may indicate a developer backdoor, debug interface, or improperly exposed internal service.
9999.remediation: 1. Identify the service running on port 9999. 2. Restrict access to trusted IPs only. 3. If unused, disable the service and close the port.
